questions.text: Hypervitaminosis A induces damage to
questions.solution:
1. Hypervitaminosis A→ retinal increases the synthesis of Lysosomal hydrolases. The manifestation of toxicity of vit. A is attributed to the destructive action of Hydrolases.
  2. Hypervitaminosis A→
  1. Excess of vit. A can lead to rupture of Lysosomal membranes
  2. C/F
  1. Acute manifestation→ Headache, vomiting and dizziness, signs of ­↑ ICT (Pseudotumor cerebri)
  2. Chronic intoxication→Anorexia, dry Itchy skin, wt. loss, painful extremities, sparse hair, Hepatosplenomegaly, hypoplastic anemia and Benign I.C. Hypertension.
  3. Normally, vit. A is stored in the liver, as an ester in the Lipocytes (Perisinusoidal stellate cells)
  4. Ito cells: fat containing Lipocytes, of mesenchymal origin are found in the space of Disse→play a role in storage and metabolism of vit. A and contribute to collagen production in normal and fibrotic liver.

questions.text: Wernicke's encephalopathy is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
1. Niacin deficiency→ Pellagra -
  2. Cyanocobalamine deficiency→ Microcystic (Megaloblastic Anemia) and sub-acute combined degeneration of spinal cord
  3. Pantothenic acid deficiency→ Burning foot syndrome
  4. Thiamine deficiency→ Beri-Beri disease, Wernicke’s encephalopathy, Korsakoff’s psychosis.

questions.text: Vitamin K dependent clotting factor are all, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
1. Vitamin K dependent clotting factors are II, VII, IX and X.
  2. Vitamin K is required for the activation of these clotting factors as it involves carboxylation of the glutamate residues of these clotting factors. Vitamin K acts as a cofactor in this carboxylation reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins becomes a major electron acceptor, aiding in the oxidation of numerous substrates?
questions.solution:
1. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD is the functional coenzyme derivative of niacin. It is the major electron acceptor in the oxidation of molecules, generating NADH, which is the major electron donor for reduction reactions.
  2. Thiamine (also known as vitamin B1) occurs functionally as thiamine pyrophosphate and is a coenzyme for enzymes such as pyruvate dehydrogenase. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) functions in the coenzyme forms of flavin mononucleotide (FMN) or flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).
  3. When concentrated, both have a yellow color due to the riboflavin they contain. Both function as prosthetic groups of oxidation-reduction enzymes or flavoproteins.
  4. Flavoproteins are active in selected oxidation reactions and in electron transport, but they do not have the ubiquitous role of NAD+.

  5. Insulin Receptor has t1/2-7 hours
  6. Number of Rs. →es on exposure of [insulin] ­

Number of Rs. →↓es in obesity and Acromegaly, excess glucocorticoids.

Number of Rs. →­↓es in starvation, in Adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: Which of the following belongs to steroidal receptor superfamily
questions.solution:
1. Hormones that bind to intracellular Receptor (i.e. steroidal receptor)
    1. Androgens, calcitriol (vit D3), Estrogens.
    2. Glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids,
    3. Progestins, Retinoic acids
    4. Thyroid hormones (T3 T4)
  2. Insulin→ acts through Receptor2, 3 →has tyrosine kinase activity.
    1. subunit→ extra cellular→ binds Insulin
    2. subunit→ transmembrane→ intracellular portion has tyrosine kinase activity and an auto phosphorylation site.
  3. The second messenger is cGMP: →atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and NO (nitric oxide)
    1. Receptors for Hormones Two major classes — Membrane and nuclear
    2. Membrane receptors — primarily bind peptide hormones and catecholamines whereas nuclear receptors bind thyroid hormones, steroids and vitamin D.
    3. Some nuclear receptors reside primarily in cytoplasm (eg. glucocorticoids receptors) whereas others (eg. thyroid hormone receptors) are always located in the nucleus.
    4. After ligand binding, the cytoplasmically localized receptors translocate to nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following act on intra cellular receptor then act through nuclear protein
questions.solution:
1. Intracellular receptors, such as nuclear receptors and cytoplasmic receptors, are soluble proteins localized within their respective areas.
  2. The typical ligands for nuclear receptors are lipophilic hormones like the steroid hormones testosterone and progesterone and derivatives of vitamins A and D. To initiate signal transduction, the ligand must pass through the plasma membrane by passive diffusion.
  3. On binding with the receptor, the ligands pass through the nuclear membrane into the nucleus, enabling gene transcription and protein production.
  4. Activated nuclear receptors attach to the DNA at receptor-specific hormone-responsive element (HRE) sequences, located in the promoter region of the genes activated by the hormone-receptor complex. Due to them enabling gene transcription, they are alternatively called inductors of gene expression. Activation of gene transcription is slower than signals directly affecting existing proteins; therefore, the effects of hormones that use nucleic receptors are long-term.
  5. Signal transduction via these receptors involves little proteins, but the details of gene regulation by this method are not well understood. Nucleic receptors have DNA-binding domains containing zinc fingers and a ligand-binding domain; the zinc fingers stabilize DNA binding by holding its phosphate backbone. DNA sequences that match the receptor are usually hexameric repeats of any kind; the sequences are similar but their orientation and distance differentiate them. The ligand-binding domain is additionally responsible for dimerization of nucleic receptors prior to binding and providing structures for transactivation used for communication with the translational apparatus.
  6. Steroid receptors are a subclass of nuclear receptors located primarily within the cytosol; in the absence of steroids, they cling together in an aporeceptor complex containing chaperone or heatshock proteins (HSPs). The HSPs are necessary to activate the receptor by assisting the protein to fold in a way such that the signal sequence enabling its passage into the nucleus is accessible.
  7. Steroid receptors, on the other hand, may be repressive on gene expression when their transactivation domain is hidden; activity can be enhanced by phosphorylation of serine residues at their N-terminal as a result of another signal transduction pathway, a process called crosstalk.
  8. Retinoic acid receptors are another subset of nuclear receptors. They can be activated by an endocrine-synthesized ligand that entered the cell by diffusion, a ligand synthesised from a precursor like retinol brought to the cell through the bloodstream or a completely intracellularly synthesised ligand like prostaglandin. These receptors are located in the nucleus and are not accompanied by HSPs; they repress their gene by binding to their specific DNA sequence when no ligand binds to them and vice versa.

 

Thyroid Hormone Receptors and Mechanism of Action:

  1. Receptors for steroid and thyroid hormones are located inside target cells, in the cytoplasm or nucleus, and function as ligand-dependent transcription factors. Receptors for thyroid hormones are intracellular DNA-binding proteins that function as hormone-responsive transcription factors, very similar conceptually to the receptors for steroid hormones.
  2. Thyroid hormones enter cells through membrane transporter proteins. A number of plasma membrane transporters have been identified, some of which require ATP hydrolysis; the relative importance of different carrier systems is not yet clear and may differ among tissues.
  3. Once inside the nucleus, the hormone binds its receptor, and the hormone-receptor complex interacts with specific sequences of DNA in the promoters of responsive genes. The effect of the hormone-receptor complex binding to DNA is to modulate gene expression, either by stimulating or inhibiting transcription of specific genes.
  4. For the purpose of illustration, consider one mechanism by which thyroid hormones increase the strength of contraction of the heart. Cardiac contractility depends, in part, on the relative ratio of different types of myosin proteins in cardiac muscle. Transcription of some myosin genes is stimulated by thyroid hormones, while transcription of others in inhibited. The net effect is to alter the ratio toward increased contractility.

choices.text: Entry of glucose in to cell

questions.text: Somatomedin are involve in:
questions.solution:
Skeletal growth with the aid of somatomedins (growth factors formed in the liver), which play a role in sulfate uptake by cartilage.

Somatomedin is a group of hormones that is produced, when stimulated by somatotropin(STH), to promote cell growth and division. In this way, they mediate the effect of somatotropin (also known as growth hormone).

They have similar biological effects to somatotropin.

Three forms include:

  1. Somatomedin A, which is another name for insulin-like growth factor 2
  2. Somatomedin B, which is derived from vitronectin
  3. Somatomedin C, which is another name for insulin-like growth factor 1

Somatomedin C = insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) inhibits the release of GH by the anterior pituitary via negative feedback control. GH has lipolytic and glycogenolytic actions that are independent of somatomedin activity.

questions.text: Following is an example of competitive enzyme blockage, except:
questions.solution:
Competitive inhibition: Km is high but Vmax is same and Reversible Eg.

  1. Lactate deHase by oxamate
  2. Aconitase by Trans Fluroacetate
  3. Succinate deHase by Malonate
  4. HMG-CoA-Reductase by HMG
  5. Dihydrofolate Reductase by Amethopterin and Trimethoprim
  6. Xanthine oxidase by Allopurinol
  7. Folate synthetase by Sulfonamides
  8. Folate reductase by Methotrexate
  9. Monoamine oxidase by MAO — inhibitors
  10. Acetylcholine esterase by physostigmine
  11. Vit. K by Dicumarol (Anti coagulant)
  12. Antimetabolites eg.→ they competitively inhibit utilization of normal substrate or get themselves incorporated forming dysfunctional macromolecules:
    1. Methotrexate competitively inhibits DHFA (folate antagonist)
    2. Purine antagonists→ eg. 6-MP, Thioguanine and Azathioprine
    3. Pyrimidine Antagonist Eg.
    4. 5- Fluorouracil à is converted in the body to the corresponding nucleotide 5-fluoro-2-deoxy-uridine monophosphate which inhibit thymidylate synthetase
    5. Cytarabine: inhibitor of DNA Polymerase→ blocks generation of cytidilic acid (s-phase specific)

Non-competitive Inhibition

  1. Reversible or Irreversible
  2. Vmax Lowered and km unaltered.

questions.text: Electrophoresis done under pH gradient is
questions.solution:
High voltage Electrophoresis (Isoelectric)→ Protein move under the influence of applied current as primary gradient in the presence of secondary gradient pH (= Isoelectric focusing)

Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis

  1. Well suited for separating the components of complex mixtures of protein
  2. IEF (isoelectric focusing) is used in conjunction with SDS-PAGE, which separate polypeptides based on PI (isoelectric point) in one dimension and based on Mr in the second.
    1. Isoelectric focusing (IEF)→ Ionic buffers called ampholytes and an applied electric field are used to generate a pH gradient with a polyacrylic amide mixture. Applied proteins migrate until they reach the region of the matrix where the pH matches their isoelectric point (p1), the pH at which a peptide’s net charge is zero.
    2. SDS-PAGE (=Sodium dodecyl sulphate — polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis)
    3. Most widely used method for determining the purity of protein (recombinant protein)
    4. Gel was stained with Coomassie blue.

questions.text: Commonest among diseases with Mendelian inheritance is
questions.solution:
Over all population frequency of Mendelian (Monogenic) disorders is 10/1000 live births of which

  1. 7/l000 is Autosomal dominant (=65%)
  2. 5/1000 is Autosomal recessive and (=25%)
  3. 4/1000 is x-linked (=5%)

questions.text: Preservative used for urine in testing for
questions.solution:
1. Porphyrins are coloured and fluorescence, while porphyrinogens are colourless.
  2. Porphyrins and their derivative, the characteristic spectrum that each exhibits, in both the visible and UV regions eg. sharp absorption curve for a solution of porphyrin 5% HC1 there is sharp absorption band near 400nm is a distinguishing feature of the porphyrin ring and is characteristic of all - porphyrins regardless of the side chains present this band is known soret (SORET) band.
  3. Strong red fluorescence, is so characteristic that it is often used to detect small amounts of free porphyrins. The double bonds joining the pyrrole ring of porphyrins, are responsible for this fluorescence.
  4. Spectrophotometry is used to test for porphyrins and their precursors.
  5. Most common type of porphyria is Porphyria Cutanea tarda.
  6. Major characteristic of Porphyria includes intermittent neurological dysfunction and skin sensitivity to sunlight but intermittent acute porphyria shows no skin photosensitivity, unlike the other types.

Excess urinary porphobilinogen excretion occurs in variegate porphyria and intermittent acute porphyria. Detection of porphobilinogen in the urine forms the basis for a positive WATSON- SCHWARTZ REACTION in the diagnosis of variegate and intermittent acute porphyria.

questions.text: Enzyme + Coenzyme constitutes
questions.solution:
1. Each enzyme has its own TERTIARY STRUCTURE and specific conformation, which is very essential for its catalytic activity (= Biological activity).
  2. The functional unit of Enzyme is known as Holoenzyme
  3. Holoenzyme=Apoenzyme+coenzyme

(Active enzyme)(Protein part)(Non-protein part)

  1. The term prosthetic group is used when the non-protein moiety tightly (covalently) binds with apoenzyme.
  2. The co-enzyme can be separated by dialysis from the enzyme while the prosthetic group cannot be.
  3. Enzymes may be defined as biocatalysts synthesized by living cells. They are protein in nature (exception –

RNA acting as ribozyme), colloidal and thermolabile in character, and specific in their action

questions.text: A male child presents with delayed development and scarring of the lips and hands. His parents have restrained him because he obsessively chews on his lips and fingers, which of the following is likely to occur in this child?
questions.solution:
The child has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome an X-linked recessive disorder that is caused by HGPRT enzyme deficiency HGPRT is responsible for the salvage of purines from nucleotide degradation, and its deficiency elevates levels of PRPP, purine synthesis, and uric acid.

  1. PRPP is also elevated in glycogen storage diseases due to increased amounts of carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: A one-year-old female patient is lethargic, weak, and anemic. Her height and weight are both low for her age. Her urine contains an elevated level of orotic acid. The administration of which of the following compounds is most likely to alleviate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
1. The elevated excretion of orotic acid indicates that the patient has orotic aciduria, a genetic disorder affecting the de novo pyrimidine biosynthetic pathway.
  2. Deficiencies in the enzyme activities OMP decarboxylase and/or orotate phosphoribosyltransferase (both of which are domains of the enzyme UMP synthase) leave the patient unable to synthesize pyrimidines.
  3. Uridine, a pyrimidine nucleoside, is useful in treating this disorder because it bypasses the missing enzymes and can be salvaged to UMP, which can be converted to all the other pyrimidines.
  4. Although thymidine is a pyrimidine nucleoside, it cannot be converted to other pyrimidines. Hypoxanthine, guanine, and adenine are all purine bases that have no value in helping to replace the missing pyrimidines.

choices.text: Cannot be used for purine synthesis

questions.text: Regarding NH3 in glutamine-true is
questions.solution:
The sources of the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the purine ring (Adenine + Guanine): Glycine provides C-4, C-5 and N-7 of the purine ring.

Amide nitrogen of glutamine provides N-3 and N-9 of purine ring



Fig.: The source of the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the purine ring. Atoms 4, 5 and 7 (shaded) derive from Glycine



  1. During purine synthesis, in second step, Amide nitrogen of glutamine (not amino gp of nitrogen), displace pyrophosphate from 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP) to form 5- phospho-b-d-ribosylamine (III).
  2. While ammonia is constantly produced in the tissue it is rapidly removed from the circulation by the liver and converted to glutamate, glutamine and ultimately to urea.
  3. In brain tissue, the major mechanism for detoxification of NH3 (Ammonia) is glutamine formation.

questions.text: Chromosomal mutations can be identified from all except
questions.solution:
1. Denaturing Gradient Gel Electrophoresis (DGGE):
  2. DNA is first extracted either from paraffin embedded or fresh tissues and subjected to denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis.
  3. The method detects selective retention of mutated BRCA1 alleles, based on the principle that different sequences of double-stranded DNA melt under different conditions.
  4. A modified form of DGGE is called as TGGE (Temperature Gradient Gel Electrophoresis) which uses temperature as a denaturing agent
  5. Nucleotide sequencing:

In this method, the complete gene is sequenced to identify the presence of any mutation in breast cancer. Till date complete gene sequencing is considered as a gold standard method because any type of mutation can be identified.  is done by two methods:

  1. Sanger's dideoxy nucleotide method
  2. Shotgun method

i Sanger Gene Sequencing: This method looks for point mutations (a change from one base pair to another), or deletions or insertions (of several bases, as opposed to an entire exon) in the dystrophin gene.

ii It can miss a few rare mutations. Sequencing can be used to locate small mutations in female carriers.

  1. Resequencing Array: This test is a chip-based sequencing method. It looks for point mutations (a change from one base pair to another), or deletions or insertions (of several bases, as opposed to an entire exon) in the dystrophin gene.

Array-based sequencing may include the entire coding region of the dystrophin gene, plus the gene promoters and some reported intronic mutations. Females can be carrier tested for small mutations using this method.

  1. Single Strand Conformational Polymorphism:
  2. This method can detect single base pair mutations like frameshift mutations, nonsense mutations and missense mutations in breast cancer.
  3. The basic principle of this test is that double stranded DNA when denatured, assumes a special conformation. This conformation is unique and depends on primary nucleotide sequence.
  4. This method is quite sensitive to detect even single nucleotide difference that occupies a different conformation and when subjected to electrophoresis, the variant nucleotide occupies a different position.

questions.text: CAP in lac operon is an example of
questions.solution:
1. Lac operon an example of negative regulation operon required for the transport and metabolism of lactose in Escherichia coli and some other enteric bacteria. It consists of three adjacent structural genes, lacZ, lacY and lacA.
  2. The lac operon is regulated by several factors including the availability of glucose and of lactose. Gene regulation of the lac operon was the first complex genetic regulatory mechanism to be elucidated and is one of the foremost examples of prokaryotic gene regulation.
  3. In its natural environment, the lac operon allows for the effective digestion of lactose. The cell can use lactose as an energy source by producing the enzyme β-galactosidase to digest that lactose into glucose and galactose.
  4. It would be inefficient to produce enzymes when there is no lactose available, or if there is a more readily-available energy source available such as glucose.
  5. The lac operon uses a two-part control mechanism to ensure that the cell expends energy producing β-galactosidase, β-galactoside permease and thiogalactoside transacetylase (also known as galactoside O-acetyltransferase) only when necessary.
  6. It achieves this with the lac repressor, which halts production in the absence of lactose, and the Catabolite activator protein (CAP), which assists in production in the absence of glucose. Thus CAP is positive regulator.
  7. This dual control mechanism causes the sequential utilization of glucose and lactose in two distinct growth phases, known as diauxie. Similar diauxic growth patterns have been observed in bacterial growth on mixtures of other sugars as well, such as mixtures of glucose and arabinose, etc.
  8. The genetic control mechanisms underlying such diauxic growth patterns are known as xyl operon and ara operon, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following method is use for detection of protein motion from cell nuclei to cytoplasm
questions.solution:
1. Fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) denotes an optical technique capable of quantifying the two dimensional lateral diffusion of a molecularly thin film containing fluorescently labeled probes, or to examine single cells.
  2. This technique is very useful in biological studies of cell membrane diffusion and protein binding. In addition, surface deposition of a fluorescing phospholipid bilayer (or monolayer) allows the characterization of hydrophilic (or hydrophobic) surfaces in terms of surface structure and free energy.
  3. Similar, though less well known, techniques have been developed to investigate the 3-dimensional diffusion and binding of molecules inside the cell; they are also referred to as FRAP.
  4. This technique is commonly used in conjunction with green fluorescent protein (GFP) fusion proteins, where the studied protein is fused to a GFP. When excited by a specific wavelength of light, the protein will fluoresce. When the protein that is being studied is produced with the GFP, then the fluorescence can be tracked.
  5. Photodestroying the GFP, and then watching the repopulation into the bleached area can reveal information about protein interaction partners, organelle continuity and protein trafficking.
  6. If after some time the fluorescence doesn't reach the initial level anymore, then some part of the fluorescence is caused by an immobile fraction (that cannot be replenished by diffusion). Similarly, if the fluorescent proteins bind to static cell receptors, the rate of recovery will be retarded by a factor related to the association and disassociation coefficients of binding.
  7. This observation has most recently been exploited to investigate protein binding.

questions.text: Subtelomeric rearrangement is detected by all except
questions.solution:
SUBTELOMERIC REARRNGEMENTAS

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH

  1. In situ hybridization, the simpler and more direct procedure, a radioactive probe is added to a metaphase spread of chromosomes on a glass slide. The exact area of hybridization is localized by layering photographic emulsion over the slide and, after exposure, lining up the grains with some histologic identification of the chromosome.
  2. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a very sensitive technique that is also used for this purpose. This often places the gene at a location on a given band or region on the chromosome. Some of the human genes localized using these techniques are listed in Table 39-5. This table represents only a sampling, since thousands of genes have been mapped as a result of the recent sequencing of the human genome.
  3. Once the defect is localized to a region of DNA that has the characteristic structure of a gene, a synthetic gene can be constructed and expressed in an appropriate vector and its function can be assessed-or the putative peptide, deduced from the open reading frame in the coding region, can be synthesized. Antibodies directed against this peptide can be used to assess whether this peptide is expressed in normal persons and whether it is absent in those with the genetic syndrome.
  4. CGH Array (Comparative Genomic Hybridization Array): Also known as array-based dosage analysis, this is a newer test that uses a microchip, and can find large deletions and duplications in any exons in the dystrophin gene. Array-based testing can identify the exact beginning and end of the deleted or duplicated part of the gene. The test can find deletions/duplications in females as well as males.
  5. MLPA (Multiple Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification): MLPA can find most large deletions, and many duplications, in the dystrophin gene. Sometimes duplications are difficult to detect using MLPA. Deletions found using this method sometimes have to be confirmed by a second testing method. This method can be used for carrier testing in females.
  6. MAPH (Multiplex Amplifiable Probe Hybridization): This type of testing can identify most large deletions and duplications in the dystrophin gene. Deletions found using this method sometimes have to be confirmed by a second testing method. This method can be used for testing of carrier females.

questions.text: Gaps between segments of DNA produced by restriction enzyme are sealed by
questions.solution:
1. Restriction enzyme breaks ssDNA or dsDNA at the restriction site.
  2. In molecular biology, DNA ligase is a special type of ligase (EC 6.5.1.1) that can link together two DNA strands that have double-strand break (a break in both complementary strands of DNA).
  3. The alternative, a single-strand break, is fixed by a different type of DNA ligase using the complementary strand as a template [citation needed] but still requires DNA ligase to create the final phosphodiester bond to fully repair the DNA.
  4. DNA ligase has applications in both DNA repair and DNA replication (see Mammalian ligases).
  5. In addition, DNA ligase has extensive use in molecular biology laboratories for Genetic recombination experiments.

Ligase mechanism

  1. The mechanism of DNA ligase is to form two between of one with the of another.

b.ATP is required for the ligase reaction

choices.text: To find out the new cloned fragment of DNA
To find out the plasmid incorporated in DNA

questions.text: Blue-white Color Screen technique is Used In DNA Cloning For?
questions.solution:
1. The vector may also include a gene spanning the cloning site which creates an easily detectible phenotype to allow for selection of inserts, such as for example the LacZα gene which is used to span a cloning site to allow for convenient blue-white color screening for recombinant vectors which include an insert at the site within the LacZα gene.
  2. The blue-white screen is a molecular technique that allows for the detection of successful ligations in vector-based gene cloning.
  3. DNA of interest is ligated into a vector. The vector is then transformed into competent cell (bacteria). The competent cells are grown in the presence of X-gal.
  4. If the ligation was successful, the bacterial colony will be white; if not, the colony will be blue.
  5. This technique allows for the quick and easy detection of successful ligation, without the need to individually test each colony.
  6. The manual enzymatic method (Sanger) employs specific dideoxynucleotides that terminate DNA strand synthesis at specific nucleotides as the strand is synthesized on purified template nucleic acid

questions.text: In sickle cell anaemia, all are correct except
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anaemia

  1. Most common hemoglobinopathy
  2. Substitution of glutamic acid residue in 6th position of β-globin chain with valine.
  3. A→T transversion
  4. HbS is less soluble in water, affinity for O2 is same
  5. In hypoxic conditions, one mutant valine side chain of deoxyhemoglobin fits into sticky patch on surface of another Hb molecule resulting in polymerization
  6. Mutation results in loss of recognition site for restriction enzyme MstII, resulting in RFLP
  7. HbS provides protection from malaria

questions.text: All are required for PCR except
questions.solution:
Polymerase Chain reaction:

It is a rapid method for amplifying a desired sequence of DNA

It requires the following:

  1. Primers: Oligonucleotides i.e. Single stranded DNA complementary to the DNA sequence of our interest
  2. dNTPs: A mixture of dATP, dGTP, dCTP, dTTP in equal conc.
  3. Mg ions
  4. Taq polymerase: Thermostable DNA polymerase obtained from Thermus aquaticus

The steps of PCR include repeated cycles of Denaturation > Annealing > Extension

Denaturation usually takes place at atemp of 94-95°C, Annealing at about 55-65°C and extension at 72°C.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT associated with protein purification and separation?
questions.solution:
Seperation of proteins

  1. On the basis of solubility: Precipitation by heavy metals, salting out: globulins are precipitated at half saturation while albumin is precipitated at full saturation with NH4Cl.
  2. On the basis of molecular size:
    1. Dialysis
    2. Gel filtration chromatography
    3. Ultra centrifugation
  3. On the basis of molecular charge:
    1. ion exchange chromatography
    2. HPLC
    3. Electrophoresis
    4. PAGE: seperation is based on sieving effects plus electrophoretic mobility
    5. SDS-PAGE:
      1. Sodium dodecyl sulphate is a strong detergent
      2. SDS imparts large negative charge to the protein
      3. Proteins are denatured
      4. Denatured proteins assume rod like shape
      5. Proteins have similar shapes and charge to mass ratio
      6. Seperation takes place on the basis of molecular mass
    1. Isoelectric focussing
  1. On the basis of affinity binding:
    1. Affinity chromatography
    2. Precipitation by antibodies

questions.text: All of the following are true about lipoprotein lipase except
questions.solution:
Lipases

Hormone sensitive lipase (HSL)

  1. Remove FA esterified to C1 of glycerol
  2. Acts on TG stores in adipose tissue

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL)

  1. Hydrolyses TG in some lipoproteins: VLDL and chylomicrons
  2. Extracellular enzyme Q adhered to endothelial cells Q via heparan sulphate Q
  3. Synthesized in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, myocardium,, lactating mammary gland, spleen, lung, kidney and aorta
  4. LPL activity is stimulated by Apolipoprotein CI and CII
  5. Deficiency in LPL leads to hyperlipoproteinaemia type I, an important feature of which is hypertriglyceridemia

Hepatic lipase

  1. Acts on TG in IDL and HDL

  • Body buffers:
    • Bicarbonate buffer: main extracellular buffer pKa=6.1
    • Phosphate buffer: major intracellular buffer pKa=6.86
    • Proteins pKa=6.0
    • Hemoglobin: major buffer in blood (effective because high in histidine and high conc. in blood) For histidine pKa=6.0
    • Ammonium buffer pKa=9.25
    • Acetate buffer pKa=4.76

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of extracellular cholesterol?
questions.solution:
1. The uptake of exogenous cholesterol by cells results in a marked suppression of endogenous cholesterol synthesis.
  2. Low-density human lipoprotein not only contains the greatest ratio of bound cholesterol to protein but also has the greatest potency in suppress ing endogenous cholesterogenesis.
  3. LDLs normally suppress cholesterol synthesis by binding to a specific membrane receptor that mediates inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl HMG coenzyme A reductase.
  4. In familial hypercholesterolemia, the LDL receptor is dysfunctional, with the result that cholesterol synthesis is less responsive to plasma cholesterol levels. Suppression of HMG CoA reductase is attained using inhibitors statins that mimic the structure of mevalonic acid, the natural feedback inhibitor of the enzyme.

questions.text: Most of the reducing equivalents utilized for synthesis of fatty acids can be generated from:
questions.solution:
1. The sources of NADPH for synthesis of fatty acids are the pentose phosphate pathway and cytosolic malate formed during the transfer of acetyl groups to the cytosol as cit rate.
  2. The enzyme citrate lyase splits citrate into acetyl CoA and oxaloacetate. The oxaloacetate is reduced to malate by NADH.
  3. NADP linked malate enzyme catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate and carbon dioxide.
  4. Thus, the diffusion of excess citrate from the mitochondria to the cytoplasm of cells not only provides acetyl CoA for synthesis of fatty acids but NADPH as well.
  5. One NADPH is produced for each acetyl CoA produced. However, most of the NADPHs needed for syn thesis of fatty acids are derived from the pentose phosphate pathway.
  6. For this reason, adipose tissue has an extremely active pentose phosphate pathway

questions.text: Transition temperature of lipid bilayers of cell membranes is increased by
questions.solution:
1. The fluid mosaic model of membrane structure proposed by Singer and Nicholson, is now widely accepted.
  2. Transition temp. Tm→ The temperature at which the structure undergoes from ordered stiff to disordered fluid, i.e. melt
    1. The Longer and more saturated fatty acid chains interacts more strongly with each other via their
    2. Longer Hydrocarbon chains→ thus ­↑Tm, ­↑stiff i.e. higher temperature is required to increase the fluidity of the bilayer.
    3. Unsaturated fatty acids: cis configuration→ ↑­fluidity of lipid bilayer i.e ↓Tm
    4. Cholesterol:-

i.At temp. below Tm→↑ fluidity

ii.At temp. above Tm →↑­ limiting the fluidity

  1. At high cholesterol: phospholipid ratio→ Transition temperature TM are abolished altogether.

questions.text: TRUE regarding the main function of Apoprotein C II
questions.solution:
1. Lipases hydrolyze blood triacylglycerol for their fatty acids to become available to tissues.
  2. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes triacylglycerol in plasma lipoproteins.
  3. Lipoprotein lipase is located on the surface of endothelial cells of capillaries and possible of adjoining tissue cells.
  4. It hydrolyzes fatty acids from the 1 and/or 3 positions of tri-and diacylglycerols present in VLDL or chylomicrons.
  5. One of the lipoprotein apoproteins (Apo C-II)must be present to activate the process. Fatty acids released are either bound to serum albumin or taken up by the tissue.
  6. Apoprotein C along with phospholipids helps in activating lipoprotein lipase for catalyzing the conversion of Chylomicrons and VLDL into Chylomicron and VLDL remnants.

Important functions of apolipoproteins:

  1. Structural component of lipoproteins
  2. Activator of enzymes:
    1. LPL: Apo CI and CII
    2. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT): AI
  3. Inhibitor of enzyme:
    1. LPL: Apo AII and CIII
    2. Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP): CI
  4. Ligand for receptors:
    1. LDL: apo B100 and apo E
    2. LRP: apo E
    3. remnant receptor: apo E
    4. HDL receptor: apo AI

questions.text: Insulin/glucagon ratio decreases in all except:
questions.solution:
The direction of change in the insulin glucagon ratio follows the direction of change of insulin, although the quantum of change is different. Thus, to predict whether a pathway is up-regulated or down-regulated by a change in insulin glucagon ratio, we need only to look at the change in insulin and effects of insulin.

Actions of insulin:

  • Increases:
    • Glycolysis
    • Glycogenesis
    • Lipogenesis
    • HMP shunt
    • Amino acid synthesis
  • Decreases:
    • Glycogenolysis
    • Lipolysis
    • gluconeogenesis
  • Inhibits: ketogenesis

questions.text: CpG islands show:
questions.solution: CpG islands represent sequences of DNA rich in C & G pairs on the same strand, which are unmethylated. Normally, CpG sequences tend to get methylated, but these CpG islands are unmethylated. CpG islands are a recent discovery in terms of functionality; they have been shown to be very strong enhancer elements. They also serve as a last resort for regulation, which is done by methylation of these islands. On methylation, their enhancer effect is lost.

questions.text: Klenow fragment is due to absence of which enzymatic activity?
questions.solution:
The Klenow fragment is a large protein fragment produced when DNA polymerase I from E. coli is enzymatically cleaved by the protease subtilisin. First reported in 1970,[1] it retains the 5' → 3' polymerase activity and the 3’ → 5’ exonuclease activity for removal of precoding nucleotides and proofreading, but loses its 5' → 3' exonuclease activity.

The other smaller fragment formed when DNA polymerase I from E.coli is cleaved by subtilisin retains the 5 ' → 3'exonuclease activity but does not have the other two activities exhibited by the Klenow fragment(i.e .5 ' → 3'polymerase activity, and 3 ' → 5'exonuclease activity).

questions.text: The mode of action of phenylbutyrate in urea cycle defects is by :
questions.solution:
Phenylbutyrate is a pro-drug, and gets converted to phenylacetate, which is the active form. Phenylacetate combines with glutamate to form the freely water soluble product, phenylacetylglutamate, which is then readily excreted in urine, thereby reducing the ammonia load of the body.

A similar mechanism of action is seen for sodium benzoate. It reacts with glycine to form hippuric acid, which is eliminated via the kidney in a single pass.

Alternate helpful molecules in urea cycle include Arginine (for deficiency of arginosuccinate Synthetase and arginosuccinate lyase) and N-carbamoyl glutamate( for deficiency of NAG synthase)

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of sugars are both non-reducing?
questions.solution:
Reducing sugars : Reducing sugars are sugars which have free aldehyde or ketonic group in their structure. Because of presence of free aldehyde or ketonic group, they can reduce certain heavy metallic cations in an alkali medium and in the process they themselves get oxidized to a mixture of sugar acids. All monosaccharides (e.g., glucose, fructose, galactose) have either free aldehyde or ketone groups. Therefore, all monosaccharides are reducing sugars.

    1. All monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose)
    2. Diasaccharide: - Lactose, maltose, cellobiose, melibiose

Non-reducing sugars

  1. Diasaccharide: - Sucrose, trehalose { Both α – glucose with α 1,1 linkage.}

choices.text: It is an Autosomal Dominant disorder
The enzyme which is defective in this condition normally oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate
Blackish pigmentation is due to accumulation of Benzoquinone acetate
Urine discolouration is due to oxidation of excreted homogentisate on prolonged exposure to air

questions.text: A 57 year old male came to OPD with complaint of joint pains and discomfort for the past several years. On examination, blackish pigmentation can be observed on his face, sclera, ear cartilage and nail beds. He also mentions that his urine turns black on exposure to air. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
OPTION A – The diagnosis of the given condition is Alkaptonuria.

  • This is Autosomal recessive disorder.

Explanation for Wrong answers

  • OPTION B – The defective enzyme is Homogentisate oxidase which oxidizes Homogentisate to mleylacetoacetate.
  • OPTION C – The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidized and polymerized forms such as Benzoquinone acetate in tissues which in turn causes blackish discolouration called as Ochronosis.
  • OPTION D -The urine darkens on exposure to air due to oxidation of excreted homogentisate.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the true/correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the true/correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text: For the following question, there is an Assertion (A) and Reasoning (R) statement. Mark the correct/True option as per the following direction: Select one of the following:
questions.solution:
• Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting branched-chain amino acids. It is one type of organic acidemia.
  • The condition gets its name from the distinctive sweet odor of affected infants' urine, particularly prior to diagnosis and during times of acute illness.
  • MSUD is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKAD), leading to a buildup of the branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and their toxic by-products (keto acids) in the blood and urine.
  • The build-up of these BCAAS will lead to the maple syrup odor that is associated with MSUD. The BCKAD complex begins by breaking down leucine, isoleucine, and valine through the use of branch-chain aminotransferase into their relevant α-keto acids.

questions.text: What type of inheritance pattern is depicted in the above pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial inherited disorders:

  1. Diabetes mellitus and deafness(DAD)
  2. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON)
  3. Leigh syndrome, subacute sclerosing encephalopathy
  4. Neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and ptosis (NARP)
  5. Myoneurogenic gastrointestinal encephalopathy (MNGIE)
  6. Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers (MERRF)
  7. Mitochondrial myopathy, encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, stroke-like symptoms (MELAS)
  8. Chronic Progressive External Opthalmoplegia (CPEO)
  9. Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS)
  10. Pearson syndrome
  11. Infantile Myopathy & Lactic acidosis (fatal & non-fatal forms)

questions.text: Inhibitor of ATP-ADP translocase is :
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of ETC:

  • Complex I:
    • Pericidin A
    • Amobarbital
    • Amytal
    • Rotenone
    • Secobarbital
    • Chlorpromazine
    • Guanethidine
    • Demerol
  • Complex II:
    • Malonate
    • Carboxin
    • TTFA (2-Thenoyltrifluoroacetone)
  • Complex III:
    • BAL
    • Antimycin A
    • Phenformin
  • Complex IV:
    • Hydrogen sulphide
    • Carbon monoxide
    • Cyanide
    • Azide
  • Complex V (ATP synthase complex):
    • Inhibitors of Fo:
      • Oligomycin
      • DCCD (Dicyclohexylcarbodiimide)
      • Venturicidin (also known as Aabomycin)
    • Inhibitors of F1:
      • Tentoxin
      • Efrapeptin
    • Inhibitors of ATP-ADP translocase:
      • Atractyloside

Uncouplers:

  • Exogenous
    • 2,4-Dinitrophenol
    • Dicumarol
    • FCCP (carbonyl cyanide-p-trifluorocarbonyl-cyanide methoxyphenyl hydrazone)
  • Endogenous:
    • via UCP-1
      • Thermogenin
    • Via UCP-3
      • Thyroxine
      • Norepinephrine
      • Epinephrine
      • Leptin
    • Via UCP-4
      • Essential fatty acid deficiency
      • Purine nucleotides
